title: GCB, Ria Introduce Remittance Service
text:
9 October 2015 15:03 CET GCB, Ria Introduce Remittance Service By Daily Guide 
Simon Dornoo (left) and El Hadj Malick Seck (right) in a hand shake after signing the deal while officials of the two institutions applaud them 
GCB Bank Limited, Ghana's largest indigenous financial institution and Ria Money Transfer, the third largest global financial institution, on Tuesday initialed an agreement that will ensure inbound remittance services throughout Ghana. 
The new agreement allows GCB customers to receive remittances in local currency at GCB's 157 branches nationwide. 
Account holders can now have funds deposited directly into their bank accounts while non-bank customers can collect remittances in cash. 
In addition to providing a secure and economical service, Ria's technology allows customers to receive rapid remittance payout within minutes. 
'With an expertise in the inbound remittance service through the largest network of 157 branches locally, this agreement with global brand Ria well positions GCB as the leading partner in the money transfer business in Ghana,' commented Simon Dornoo, MD of GCB Bank. 
He added that Ria's global network will afford GCB the opportunity to mobilize remittances from Ghanaians in the Diaspora for their relatives at home.' 
According to Mr Dornoo, remittances, which were the second highest international inflow of funds to developing nations, including Ghana, were expected to reach $440 billion in 2015. 
Ria's President and CEO, Juan Bianchi, stated that the partnership is aligned with Ria's vision to improve financial inclusion worldwide. 
'Our agreement with GCB Bank Ltd gives more choice to Ghanaians and others living abroad to send money home to their family and friends.' 
Robert Kotei, Operations Director, Ria Africa and El Hadj Malick Seck, Managing Director, Ria Africa observed that the collaboration would serve as a perfect tool for money transfers, as users could transfer funds from their accounts to relatives by employing the use of their Remittance Pay out Service.
